Note

This article was originally written and submitted for grading on April 27th 2014. It received one of the highest marks in that class. It was the very last academic essay I wrote (and still proud of). It was written for my last English as Second Language (ESL) course when I was an undergraduate student at University of Wisconsin Madison. It is a long article, and the article itself is not free from grammatical mistakes, you have been warned.

It's been 12 years, censorship still exists in China and the situation has gotten worse everywhere else around the world. I think it is important for me to leave this article here to remind myself I have done some research on this topic before, and it should not be forgotten.

FOR ANY READER FROM CHINA, PLEASE DO NOT SPREAD THIS ARTICLE IN CHINA, THIS IS FOR YOUR SAFETY

Internet is an important tool in modern society, people use it every day to interact with each other. Censorship, as exists in other kind of medium, exist within the internet. As the internet grows and evolves over time, the internet censorship also evolves. Bambauer (2012) believed that during the early stage of censorship, which he referred to as Censorship v1.0, censorship on the internet is impossible. When the censorship was applied for the first time, which he referred to as Censorship v2.0, only a few countries applied this technology, and the content that were filtered were usually politically related. When more and more countries created their own censorship system and started to censor the internet, internet censorship evolves to become Censorship v3.0. At this stage, countries censored information regardless of their political system. The purpose is usually described as protecting citizens (p. 3). For western countries, information censored are usually related to child pornography, hate speech, and material that may violate copyright (Bambauer, 2012, p. 3). The internet censorship system in China, however, is described as something in stage 2. Bambauer (2012, p. 3) pointed out that that censorships are acceptable if citizens in these countries are notified. However, the situation is not the same in China. As one of the largest countries in the world, China has created the most sophisticated censorship system in the world. This system targets mainly at social media platforms.

Despite the fact that Facebook and Twitter are two of the most popular social networking sites in the world, only a small amount of people in China are able to access them. Yet, people in China are active on the Chinese alternative of these social networking sites. Based on the report by Synthsio (2013), Weibo, a Twitter-like social media platform created by Sina company in 2009, has gained 209 million users by the end of 2012. Qzone, which is a social media platform created by Tencent company, has gained 600 million active users (p. 8). The amount of users on both platforms are large enough to demonstrate that Chinese people are quite active on the internet. It may even create a false sense that people in China are able to express their ideas freely or discuss current affairs on these social media platforms. However, a close analysis on a recent event and how government acted during the event reveals that even though people are able to discuss more about public events in recent years, the censorship on social media still exists. Through quick deletion of posts related to unwanted information on domestic social media platforms and blocking foreign social media sites, Chinese government is able to control the social media and maintain the status quo.

As alternatives to Twitter and Facebook, Weibo and Qzone provide people with an important way to express their opinions on current events. On July 23rd 2011, two high speed train crashed into each other near the city of Wenzhou, Zhejiang Province. According to CNN (Jiang, 2011), at least 38 people were killed including two Americans. Despite the fact that journalists from around the country tried their best to arrive at Wenzhou as soon as possible, CNN emphasized that major news media in China did not report about this news the next day. On the contrary, Weibo, as a social media platform, was where people got first-hand information about this event. In fact, the first report and SOS post sent by passengers on the train was just 13 minutes after the crash happed (Wu, 2012, p. 7). Wu (2012) pointed out that the official rescue of the survivors was concluded by the Ministry of Railways 7 hours after the train crash. Yet, a 2-year-old survivor was found and saved by the SWAT team 21 hours after this serious disaster (p. 2). Though this lucky girl survived the accident, she was heavily injured and lost both of her parents, she was blessed by netizens around the country, hoping that she could get well soon. Meanwhile, doubts were arose about whether the Ministry of Railway had put enough effort on rescuing. The ministry, however, gave the worst answer they can give.

CNN reported that when being asked about why the ministry stopped rescue work while there were people still alive, the spokesperson from the Ministry of the Railways said that they had put enough effort in rescue and regarded the survival of the little girl as "a miracle" (Jiang, 2011). This, as Wu (2012) commented, trigged large amount of criticism directed toward the Ministry as well as the Chinese government on Weibo (p. 2). By analyzing 330 posts from eight users who started to use "Wenzhou High Speed Train" as part of their account name on Sina Weibo during the event, Wu identified that 38% of the posts were related to criticism of the Railway Ministry (p. 13). Needless to say, due to the lack of efforts made by the Railway Ministry as well as the distrust of the state controlled media, Weibo had become a place for Chinese netizens to express their opinion toward the collision disaster. However, several days after the event, the intervention made by the government caused significant change to what people can express on Weibo.

The Weibo, as a representation of the social networking sites in China, provided netizens with a space to express their opinions during the Wenzhou high speed train collision. Unfortunately, the censorship system was also triggered as the Weibo posts related to criticism of the government increased. Chinese Digital Times, which is supported by School of Information at UC-Berkley, regards itself as an independent media that report China without being censored. They reported that the censorship was applied by the Chinese government two days after the disaster. It is reported that the Central Propaganda Department urge Chinese media not to report any news related to the crash on their front page and that all posts on social media that are related to the event ought to be deleted immediately ("Directives from the Ministry of Truth," 2011). Although it is hard to verify whether the department had released this kind of command, findings based on the data provided by Wu accidentally endorsed that the command might be true. It can be noticed from the graph given by Wu (2012, p. 8) that the amount of Weibo tweets posted by the eight users that he tracked reduced significantly from above 100 posts per day to under 20 posts per day during a specific period in between July.23rd to July.30th. For the 8 users that Wu tracked, this amount of posts on the event during that time were truly abnormal. The deletion practice might be a reasonable explanation for this sharp decrease. If this assumption is true, then the fast speed in deleting posts may also imply that the censorship system in China does its job quite efficiently.

A group of researchers focused on 3,567 users who talked about sensitive political topics on Weibo regularly made the same conclusion. They attested that 30% of the deletion occurred in less than 30 minutes after the content was posted, and only 10% of the posts were deleted after 24 hours (Zhu, Phipps, Pridgen, Crandall, & Wallach, 2013, p. 12). Though Zhu et al. made their conclusions based on a small sample group relative to the large amount of users who use Weibo, it can be assumed that with more users, the amount of posts that need to be deleted will only increase and thus requires more effort. For other social media platforms in China, including forum posts and blog posts, researchers have reached the same conclusion as Zhu et.al. By analyzing 11,382,221 posts King et al.(2014) concluded that the majority of posts related to the topics that they tracked were censored within one day after posting (p. 330). To reach the goal of making deletions of Weibo as well as other social media platforms effectively, it is necessary for the government to implement the correct method.

The method used by Chinese government is complicated and due to the fact that the censorship in China is not transparent, a lot of assumptions have been made on the methods used for censorship. Most studies have highlighted the use of keyword filtering. It is believed that this method stops people from posting content that contain specific keywords (King, Pan, & Roberts, 2013, p. 328). To use this method, censors can either prevent users from posting the content that includes the keyword or delete the content with the keywords after they are posted. However, as it is impossible for people to actually access the list of blocked keywords, lots of researchers have attempted to make assumptions on the blocked lists of keywords. King et .al. (2014) referred the technology of censoring prior to posting as "automated review" and by creating and running their own forum in China, these researchers got an idea of how "automated review" worked. They pointed out that when the posts submitted by user match specific keywords, it will not be posted immediately but will be held for administrators to review. By reverse engineering, they found out that most of the keywords were usually suggesting collective action or opinions on the government. However, they also mentioned that websites in China including BBS and those which allow people to make follow up comments did not rely heavily on this automated technology as every posts or comments were still read in order to keep accuracy of the censorship (p. 20). Zhu et al. (2013) described a similar finding while analyzing Sina Weibo. They wrote that while trying to post a string containing the word "政法委书记" (Secretary of the Political and Legislative Committee), their posts were immediately rejected with a warning saying that they had violated certain Weibo regulations (this is probably because this secretary was under investigation for corruption at that time and people were not allowed to discuss that publicly). When they tried to submit another post containing the phrase "Falun" (representing a banned religious in China), the post was not posted immediately but submitted for review and appeared 5 hours later (p. 6). The consistent finding from King et al. and Zhu et al. indicated that automated censorship technology are largely used by Chinese social media sites.

However, it is believed that this technology is not good enough to ensure that "unwanted" information are censored. This is mainly because of the characteristic of the Chinese language. Over time, Chinese netizens have developed the method of substituting words that may potentially be censored with other words with irrelevant meaning but sound or look alike (King et al., 2013, p. 328). Example for this include 目田 (meaning eye field) represented the blocked word 自由 (which means freedom) (King et al., 2013, p. 328). 自由 and 目田 looked very much alike, but the latter one is meaningless. Another choice of netizens is to use words that sound the same to replace the sensitive keywords. 毒豺 (which means poisonous dhole if translated directly) is used to represent the blocked word独裁 (which means dictatorship), these two words sounds similar but the first one has no meaning to censors. There are many more examples of the same kind of words that were created by netizens to avoid censorship. It is believed that when using these replacement characters, the automated censorship will not be able to identify them as keywords and netizens can bypass the censorship easily. This reveals that the automatic keyword censorship is not reliable and to become more accurate in filtering information, websites have to put a moderate amount of effort on censorship after the information is posted.

King et al. and other researchers find that for information that is already posted, manual intervention by censors has to be done. King et al. (2013) explained how manual censorship worked in forums and other blogging websites, this excluded the Weibo created by Sina. They found that for manual censorship, the method of substitution would no longer be effective. They noticed that to achieve the goal of manual censorship, government and websites have to form consensus on what to censor and ask thousands of individuals to do the censorship work within 24 hours (p. 330). This implied that the manual censorship requires a lot of individuals in order to do their job quickly which means these people have to be professional in identifying and censoring "unwanted" information. CNN reporters estimated that the number of people that Chinese government employed to do manual censorship was around 2 million in 2013, which is more than people served in the army (Hunt & Xu, 2013, p. 1). This number might be large, but as the number of netizens online is even larger, the actual number of censors might be much larger than this rough estimate. Other researchers gave assumptions about the kind of posts that are most likely to be deleted. According to the research conducted by Bamman et al., posts with certain set of words are most likely to be deleted. They argue that these posts not only include commonly known terms that are sensitive due to politics but also include those that had become sensitive because of current events (Bamman, O'Connor, & Smith, 2012, p. 15). Obviously, the censorship implemented by the government had negative influence on what people can express on social media platforms inside China. However, for popular social networking websites that are not in China, a different method is used to achieve the same goal.

Though effort put on the censorship of domestic social media platforms is impressive, it is impossible for the Chinese government to control social networking sites that were not created by Chinese company, they chose to block these websites completely. When foreigners come to China for the first time, they might be surprised when trying to access Facebook or Twitter as the only thing they are able to get is an error screen rather than the normal websites no matter how many times they try. China, as described in Facebook's IPO filing, is one of the four countries (China, Iran, North Korea, and Syria) that completely or partially block access to Facebook (Constine, 2012, p.3). Other websites that are blocked include Twitter, YouTube and Google plus which are all popular social networking sites around the world. In an effort to block these websites, a certain technology have to be implemented to the whole internet in China.

The Great Firewall of China is the main effort made by Chinese government to block access to these websites. Fang Binxing, who is the former president of Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications, is commonly regarded as the founder of the Great Firewall of China. It is believed that Fang's effort in building the Great Firewall started in 1999, and over the years the censorship system has evolved (Anonymous, 2013). According to the Economists(2013) that in early years, the Great Firewall only take into account websites that had strong relevance to sensitive political topics in China. However, in recent years, the Great Fire wall is becoming smarter. When user tried to access Facebook and Twitter, they will be taken to an error page. It is also believed that when users searched for certain words on Google, their access to the search engine will blocked for 90 seconds though the user still have access to other websites (p. 2). Facebook and Google and not the only websites that are affected by the Great Firewall. In an early study conducted by Zittrain and Edelman (2003, p. 71), they found that 18,931 websites were inaccessible from within China. This indicated that if the assumption raised by the anonymous writer about the evolvement about Great Firewall is true, the blocked websites will greatly increase. To correctly block the large number of websites, it is important for the Great Firewall to use a correct methodology.

It is commonly believed that the Great Firewall was implemented at a national level, and lots of methods were used in order to achieve the goal of blocking. Wright (2014, p. 121) highlighted the use of DNS poisoning method used by the Great Firewall. DNS, which is short for Domain Name Server, is what provides the computers with the correct IP address of the websites that users want to visit so that they are directed correctly. The DNS poisoning method that Wright referred to will provide users with the wrong address for the websites they want to visit and they will then be directed to an error page or even a fake website. According to Wright (2014), the DNS poisoning method varies by provinces in China and the type of error given by DNS server in different province is quite different (p. 122). This indicated even though the Great Firewall and censorship policy are enforced at a national level, the specific implementation of this policy varies.

Another finding indicated that "TCP reset packets" are used when certain key words is found while inspecting the TCP packets (Clayton, Murdoch, & Watson, 2006, p. 1). TCP packets are known as the information that are transmitted between users and websites, when the "TCP reset packets" were sent, users are not likely to receive the real information they requested from the server. Clayton et al. (2006) noticed that even when the "TCP reset packets" were sent, the correct packets were still transmitted. Their experiment also showed by ignoring the "wrong packets" sent intentionally by the Great Firewall, they were still able to access the blocked websites (p. 15). Even though this sounds complicated, it is actually easy to bypass the Great Firewall in practice.

While Twitter is blocked in China, some report showed that China has 35million of active users on Twitter as of the second quarter of 2012. This number was estimated after seven surveys during 2009 with a total sample of 8000 people conducted by GlobalWebIndex Market Company(Ong, 2012). This number is most likely to be untrue as many Chinese people do not even have an idea of what Twitter is. However, a later study might provide a better idea for this number. By carefully examining the language of the tweet as well as the time zone which the user belongs to, the number of Chinese users on Twitter is estimated to be 8,000 (Millward, 2013, p. 2). Though 8,000 is pretty small when compare to the number of people who use Sina Weibo, it clearly shows that people in China have method to bypass the intervention of the Great Firewall. Bamman et al. (2012) made a comparison between posts that were posted in Chinese on Weibo and Twitter. They revealed that users were able to talk about politics more freely on Twitter. He demonstrated in a graph that posts containing three highly political related names are significantly more on Twitter than on Weibo (p.8). Thus, it can be inferred that the block of Twitter and many other social networking sites that are not based in China are more likely due to political reasons.

Some people may argue that Chinese people do not actually care about whether the internet is censored. Jenkins cited Yang and argue that most of the people in China firmly believed that the government is correct on internet censorship. They believed that the internet censorship in China is just a "moral measurement" made by the Chinese government to enforce its role as an internet regulator (Yang, 2013, p. 3). In my opinion, it is also believed that due to the spread of rumors on Weibo and other unhealthy information on the internet, keeping the censorship is necessary for the government to maintain a stable society. However, it is worth noting that this "moral measurement" implemented by the Chinese government may also trigger outrage among certain group of people in China. GitHub, a popular community for software developers around the world to learn and communicate with each other, was blocked by the Great Firewall in early 2013. This made the software developers in China angry as they believe blocking such website is unreasonable and it will be difficult for them to access good resources that may help their development if the website is blocked (Ivan Zhai, 2013). This indicated that there are people who care about the censorship and the censorship were not solely for moral purposes. In the long term, the extensive censorship will make it difficult for people to share and retrieve information on foreign websites and hurt the researches in China.

In conclusion, though censorship exists in China, people have gained some opportunities to express their opinions thanks to the raise of Weibo and other social media platforms. As maintaining the censorship will be beneficial to the government to keep the status quo, internal censorship will exists in the coming future for most websites based in China. The external blockage of some of the social networking sites that were not created in China will also continue to limit how people can get information through internet. In the future, the game between censorship and Chinese netizens will not end. But as the technology advances, the censorship will better. With advanced censorship, it is likely that more people will try to find why they were blocked and more and more people will be able to bypass the Great Firewall eventually.

Recently, I finished working on a project that deals with mTLS in Java, more specifically, it was to setup mTLS to connect to a message queue. After quite a lot of effort, I finally got everything working correctly. Hopefully this article can be helpful to readers seeking help on this topic.

TLS

To understand what mTLS or mutual TLS is, we first need to understand what TLS is. TLS stands for Transport Layer Security, it is the defector protocol to provide communications security over the network.

The best place to understand this is through the TLS standards document. According to the TLS 1.3 standards document or rfc84461:

[...]
TLS allows client/server applications to communicate over the Internet in a way that is designed to prevent eavesdropping, tampering, and message forgery.
[...]
The primary purpose of TLS protocol is to provide a secure channel between two communicating peers.

To conform to the TLS protocol, this specific secure channel should provide authentication, confidentiality and integrity. For the server side of this secure channel, authentication is mandatory; while for client side, authentication is optional. Data sent through the channel after establishment is only visible to the endpoints, and the data can not be modified by attackers without detection.

The TLS protocol consists of two main components: the handshake protocol and the record protocol. The RFC document described the handshake protocol in detail:

[...]
The handshake protocol is used to negotiate the security parameters of a connection.
[...]
The TLS handshake is an Authenticated Key Exchange (AKE) protocol which is intended to provide both one-way authenticated (server-only) and mutually authenticated (client and server) functionality.

The handshake process can be divided into three phases: Key Exchange, Server Parameters and Authentication. The process starts with a ClientHello message described below.

The server will respond to this message with a ServerHello message, if it is able to negotiate:

This completes the Key Exchange phase of the handshake. Immediately following the ServerHello message, the server will send the EncryptedExtensions, and optionally CertificateRequest if the server requires client-based authentication.

That is the end of the server parameters phase and the start of authentication phase.

The start of the authentication phase will be a Certificate message from the server, and the client will also send a Certificate message if it has received a CertificateRequest message previously. Most notably, the Certificate presented by both the server and the client must be of X509 type. And the RFC specifically mentioned scenarios where a bad_certificate alert will be sent:

Any endpoint receiving any certificate which it would need to validate using any signature algorithm using an MD5 hash MUST abort the handshake with a "bad_certificate" alert. SHA-1 is deprecated, and it is RECOMMENDED that any endpoint receiving any certificate which it would need to validate using any signature algorithm using a SHA-1 hash abort the handshake with a "bad_certificate" alert. For clarity, this means that endpoints can accept these algorithms for certificates that are self-signed or are trust anchors.

The CertificateVerifiy message follows the Certificate message, and is used to provide explicit proof that an endpoint possesses the private key corresponding to its certificate. This is achieved by providing a signature signed using the private key and the other party verify the signature using the public key.

In typical HTTPS (or HTTP over TLS) communication, the HTTP client would also act as TLS client, the client can only initiate HTTP request once the TLS handshake has been completed 2. However, in mutual TLS setting, as mentioned above, the client will need to provide certificate to authenticate itself as well.

Java keystore and keytool

For developers who have used Java before, keystore shouldn't be an unfamiliar concept. It is used to store keys and certificates. A keystore can have two distinct kind of entries: key entry and Trusted certificate entries.

A key entry can contain a private key, an X.509 certificate (can be v1, v2, or v3) containing the public key that matches this entry's private key. Optionally, one or more CA certificates that belong to the preceding certificate's trust chain3.

Note that a private key entry can have its own password, this can cause issue if that password is different from the one for keyStorePassword. It's better to always set them to the same or just remove the password from the privateKey before adding it to the keystore.

Tips, Caveats and Issues

Dealing with TLS and certificate is not a pleasant experience, especially when it involves Java and keystore, so I would like to share some tips and caveats I encountered during the process:

  • Useful OpenSSL commands:
  • Debugging: I added -Djavax.net.debug=ssl:keymanager:trustmanager:session -Djava.security.debug=certpath while I was debugging the certificate related issue, it is quite verbose logging but was quite helpful.
  • Java Keystore certificate selection: What happens if a Java keystore has multiple private key entries and we use the method described above to set keystore? The answer is complicated, but it is documented here. In short, better to avoid this issue by only having one private key per keystore.
  • Certificate used for mTLS authentication: Ideally, a certificate should have clientAuth in its extended usage section to be used for mTLS (though this may not always be an issue).
  • If you encounter bad_certificate error, this is likely you are using a certificate that requires MD5 or SHA-1 as signature algorithm.
  • If you encounter password error when accessing the keystore, it could be you give the wrong keystore password, or it could also be your private key has a different password from the keystore password which is not supported by Java.

Recently I got myself a Rock 4 C+ single board computer. This is a SBC that was released in 2022, so it is a bit old. From the spec, this thing looks quite promising. It has a Rockchip RK3399T SoC that uses Arm® big.LITTLE™ technology (Dual Cortex®-A72 frequency 1.5GHz and a Quad Cortex-A53 frequency 1.0GHz). And dual channel 4GB 64bit LPDDR4 memory and dual micro-HDMI output. At 47 NZD (exclude shipping cost), it's definitely a bargain (the Raspberry Pi 3b+ cost more than that, and it only got 1GB RAM)

In this article, we will go through the process of installing ArchLinux on this Rock 4C+ single board computer.

Initial Investigation

Let's start by exploring around and finding the existing resources first.

The first choice in this case would be to look at the officially supported distro from the vendor. It turned out the vendor provided several distros to choose from^1. However, they are not up-to-date -- most of them were last updated in 2023.

The next place to look at would be the wiki, specifically the archlinux arm wiki. It turned out, there is no official wiki for this model. The closest article is for Rock64, which is a completely different model ^2.

Initial Installation

Install the ArchLinux is not as difficult as one might think. We can selectively followed the Rock64 Wiki article and loaded Linux onto a brand new 64G MicroSD card. Once we finished the installation, we can follow steps here and chroot into the installation and installed some of the packages that's necessary (e.g. sudo, wget).

We are one step closer to be able to boot the system, however, we are missing an important part -- the bootloader.

Compile and flash the bootloader

The bootloader for this specific board is not readily available, so we only two choices:

  • Extract the bootloader for this board from the readily available distro vendor provided.
  • Compile the mainline bootloader on my own and install it.

We are going to choose the later one for the sake of this article. It is not an easy task, but this well written wiki article on Gentoo Linux website will help us a lot through out the process.

The commands we need to use will be a bit different from the wiki article depending on the distro.
Here's some tips for cross compile on Arch:

  • When cross compile the bl31 on x86, be sure to use: MAKEOPTS="-j$(nproc) -l$(nproc)" FEATURES=$FEATURES" -distcc -distcc-pump" PLAT=rk3399 CROSS_COMPILE=aarch64-linux-gnu- make bl31. Note aarch64-linux-gnu- instead of aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu-
  • When cross compile the u-boot, be sure to use: MAKEOPTS="-j$(nproc) -l$(nproc)" FEATURES=$FEATURES" -distcc -distcc-pump" PLAT=rk3399 CROSS_COMPILE=aarch64-linux-gnu- BL31=./bl31.elf make

Once the bootloader compiled, we will need to write them to the MicroSD card

IMPORTANT: Remember to replace the sdX with the actual mount point

At this point, the MicroSD card that has both the bootloader and the ArchLinux image loaded. But the bootloader still has no idea about what and where to load the things necessary to boot up. This is where the boot.txt or u-boot boot script image comes into play

U-boot boot script

The next step is to setup a boot.txt file to tell u-boot where to load the kernel and device tree from. Here's the boot.txt I created:

In the code above, some of the variables are default environment variables from u-boot, this manual contains more information about the details on environment variables in u-boot.

In order for u-boot to use this script, we need to compile it to an image with the following command:

(on ArchLinux, mkimage is part of uboot-tools package)

This is the last step before we unmount the MicroSD card from our computer and put it into the physical board. If everything goes well, you should be greeted with the ArchLinux console login when you boot.

Post Installation fixes

WiFi

The Rock4 C+ board comes with WiFi and Bluetooth with external antenna. However, we will soon realize the WiFi is not working properly after boot. This is because, we need to manually adding some file in order to load the WiFi driver.

We will need to extract the needed file from the vendor image, and copy it into /lib/firmware/brcm folder. The file we are looking for is brcmfmac43455-sdio.txt.

Recently, I found myself needing to run virtual machines quite often, however, with two different types of VMs managed by different hypervisors on my machine, I find it quite inefficient to click through multiple hoops in GUI just to launch a single VM. Therefore, decided to spend time to find ways to improve this workflow.

The start: Controlling hypervisors from CLI and alias

As I mentioned previously, I ran two different types of Hypervisors on my machine:

  • VirtualBox (For Windows guests)
  • QEMU (For Linux guests)
    Let's dive into how to control the hypervisors from CLI

VirtualBox

In the past, I have attempted to start VirtualBox automatically on Windows host and wrote about it, this mostly involved running a batch script that can control the VirtualBox from the command line.

Quite conveniently, on Linux, we can use almost the same exact command to control things, so

  • To list all the available guests: vboxmanage list --sorted vms
  • To start a guest, we can use: vboxmanage startvm NAME_OF_GUEST
  • To power off a guest, we can use vboxmanage controlvm NAME_OF_GUEST poweroff

QEMU

To control guests managed by KVM, we will need to use virsh. Virsh is part of the libvirt project, which aims to provide a toolkit to manage virtualisation platforms ^1. We can use the following commands to find and manage KVM guests:

  • To list all the available guests, we can use: virsh --connect=qemu:///system list --all
  • To start a given guest, we can use: virsh --connect=qemu:///system start NAME_OF_GUEST
  • To power off a given guest, we can use: virsh --connect=qemu:///system shutdown NAME_OF_GUEST

You may wonder why we need --connect=qemu:///system part in the virsh command above. This is because normally, we would need to run virsh as root (so with sudo). However, if you are a member of the libvirt group, you can use the --connect=qemu:///system. This make things a bit more convenient, especially when we need to use the command in a script.

Using alias

It's not difficult to realize, we can greatly simplify our workflow to start a VM if we add them as alias in our bash or zsh config file. For example:

We will be able to avoid typing the command each time with this, however, it is not a sustainable solution as we could have more than 5 guests on the host, and remembering those aliases will quickly become a burden.

Experimentation: Launching from Polybar and Rofi

The next attempt I made was using Polybar and Rofi. In my previous article on opening Zoom with a single click, I explored the possibility of combining Polybar and rofi by adding a new custom script launcher in Polybar. We can use a similar solution here.

Let's create the following script for VirtualBox first:

The awk command is used to sanitize the output of the command and leave only VM name, other part of the command is straightforward, so I wouldn't get into details on this.

A similar one can be created for virsh. I used the following for the script:

This works almost perfectly. However, I still have to move the mouse to click on the icon on the Polybar whenever I want to launch a guest machine. This is still not efficient enough for me.

Solution: Application Entry with Rofi

After much searching, I ended up creating an application entry for the launcher. More specifically, here's the steps I took:

  • Create an entry under $HOME/.local/share/applications/vm.desktop
  • Inside this entry, I put the following content
  • Then I copied the script I created for the launcher to $HOME/local/bin and named it libvirt_dmenu, I also made sure $HOME/local/bin is in my $PATH
  • With this settings, I can open the VM menu by just typing in mvm in the rofi dialogue, this greatly simplify things as I can control the VM directly from the rofi.

Bonus: Rofi calculator

After doing this, I realized it's a good idea to create something similar for the calculator as well. I'm so used to Alfred on MacOS where I can directly calculate in the command palette. I did found something similar for rofi called rofi-calc ^2. It is built on top of the Qalculate ^3, which is likely one of the best calculators available on Linux.

Similar to the entry above, we can create the following for the calculator functionality:

With this in-place, whenever we need a simple calculation, we can type == in rofi command palette and get the result from Qalculate.

We can also add a tray icon on Polybar:

Clicking on the icon will bring up the Qalculator.

Lessons learnt

I started experimenting with Rofi and dmenu because I need to optimize my workflow, and I'm glad I achieve what I needed. Rofi, dmenu and Application Entry are really powerful tools on Linux, it is a great idea to utilizing this tool and optimize efficiency.

Hi there, thanks for reading this. My name is Sicong Jiang, and I'm a software engineer based in Auckland, New Zealand. I'm part of the One Byte Bandits team on HTB, and this is my first time participating in a CTF. I decided to challenge myself with a hard forensics challenge, and it turned out to be quite interesting. I hope you enjoy this journey of solving the Tales of the Brave challenge together.

Introduction

Let's read through the instructions first:

Tales for the Brave
In Eldoria, a once-innocent website called "Tales for the Brave" has become the focus of unsettling rumors. Some claim it may secretly trap unsuspecting visitors, leading them into a complex phishing scheme. Investigators report signs of encrypted communications and stealthy data collection beneath its friendly exterior. You must uncover the truth and protect Eldoria from a growing threat.
When debugging JavaScript, ensure you use a Firefox-based browser.

There are several things to note here:

  • Once-innocent website: This challenge involves web security.
  • When debugging JavaScript, ensure you use a Firefox-based browser: We should use Firefox.
  • Encrypted communications and stealthy data collection: This suggests hidden or obfuscated behavior.

First Look

To get started, we paste the URL into the browser. The challenge specifically mentions using Firefox, so let's go with that. After launching Firefox, I took my first look at the website. It does seem quite innocent, right?

It's just a form with some checkboxes—what harm can it do? Let's try interacting with it by filling out the form and clicking some random checkboxes.

Then I submitted it:

Hmm, nothing happened—except for this pop-up.

Digging into the JavaScript

You wouldn't expect to get the flag in a popup for a hard challenge, would you? Let's inspect the HTML code.

The webpage loads two JavaScript files: index.js and crypto-js.js. Since crypto-js.js is loaded from Cloudflare, it’s likely a standard library. So let’s focus on index.js.

This is heavily obfuscated code—no wonder it’s a hard challenge.

Let's take a deep breath and analyze what it does. The first line defines a variable:

We don’t need to understand how it's defined—just its value. Since it's in the global scope, we can execute window._$_9b39 in the console to retrieve it:

Now that we understand the variable definitions, let's see how they interact with the eval() function. According to MDN, eval() evaluates JavaScript code represented as a string and returns its result.

The key part of the parameter being evaluated can be rewritten as:

CryptoJS provides an example of AES decryption:

Setting up a breakpoint at the .toString function in crypto-js.js and stepping through it with a debugger helps us understand its purpose.

The decrypted result is an unformatted script passed to eval(). We can format it manually or step through the debugger. I chose the latter and formatted the code in the debugger. Here’s the beautified version:

Cracking the Telegram Bot

To forward a message to a Telegram chat, we first need a chat ID. But before that, we must identify the bot’s username. Telegram provides an API for retrieving bot info:

Replacing {token} with our retrieved token reveals the bot’s username:

Next, we create a chat with the bot and obtain the chat ID using:


Entering the chat.id into the description field sends a message, but I encountered an error in the console initially:

HTB Ticket

Since this error was on Telegram’s side, I opened a ticket with HTB on Discord.

HTB quickly resolved the issue, but the bot sent an expired invite link.

HTB staff confirmed the link should be expired. Looking for alternative clues, I forwarded message IDs from 6 to 12 and got a zip file with a password. Extracting it yielded a Windows binary: Brave.exe.

Tricking Brave.exe for the Flag

Reversing the binary seemed necessary, but I lacked the tools. Fortunately, Carl (Spymky) from my team stepped in. He loaded it in Ghidra but made little progress. Switching to dynamic analysis, he considered online sandboxes like Any.Run and Joe Sandbox but opted for a local VM with Wireshark.

Installing the Brave browser and running Brave.exe revealed this:

The binary accessed zolsc2s65u.htb, a non-public domain. Adding this to the hosts file solved the issue:

Running the binary again, Wireshark captured traffic to port 31337. I spun up a web server:

Filtering HTTP traffic revealed a POST request with a Bearer token.

Decoding it in CyberChef uncovered the flag! 🎉🥳

Acknowledgment

Special thanks to Carl (Spymky) from my team for helping analyze Brave.exe!

Conclusion

This was my first CTF, but definitely not my last. Debugging skills played a crucial role in solving this challenge. CTFs are challenging yet rewarding, requiring patience and tenacity. I hope you found this write-up insightful and learned something new!

What?

Before we go into the investigation, it is important to define the goal first. The goal here, is automate the process of building iOS/Android app from source using command line and deploy the application to the iOS/Android simulator separately.

Detect the project type based on certain criteria

Recently, I've done something with the DNS setup in my local networking. I learnt quite a lot along the way and have decided to write it down for my reference, and for other people who might find this useful.

Background

I have a quite simple home network setup. My main router is a Linksys WRT1200AC which is running OpenWrt 24.10 branch. I have installed Adblock, Unbound, Stubby, and many other software on this router and even after 10 years, it is still performing well.

My main homelab server is a Raspberry Pi 5 (8 GB) which I bought recently to replace my Rapsberry Pi 3. As I have mentioned in my previous articles on self hosting and nebula, this Raspberry Pi has been running quite a lot of containers along with the Traefik proxy for quite a while now.

Motivation

I often need to setup private domains within my homelab, mainly to experiment with new software. What I want to achieve is within my local LAN network, every device can resolve these private domains and whenever a new private domain is added, it will take effect automatically without my manual intervention.

For example, in my local network, wallabag.raspberrypi.lan would take me to the wallabag container and static.raspberry.lan would take me to the Nginx container, they are both running on my Raspberry Pi. And lab.raspberrypi.lan would also resolve to the IP of my Raspberry Pi without any intervention.

The rest of this article will focus on how I achieved the solution that solved both of this problem.

(Note: you might need to flush your DNS cache with sudo systemd-resolve --flush-caches)

Naive Solution: Modify hosts file on one device

While this may not be what the readers are expecting, it is a solution most people would attempt first. Hosts files are mappings between the host name and IP addresses ^1. To access wallabag.raspberrypi.lan from a particular device, you can simply add the domain and IP to the hosts file of that device.

As an example, on Linux, if you add wallabag.raspberrypi.lan 192.168.1.134 to a device's hosts file (located at /etc/hosts), the domain wallabag.raspberrypi.lan will resolve to 192.168.1.134 on this device.

Obviously, this is not a great solution -- it doesn't achieve what I want. You won't be able to modify the hosts file on your mobile device running iOS or Android easily. And each time you want to experiment with a new domain, you will have to manually add them to your hosts file which will be less than ideal.

Improved Solution: Modify Local DNS

This second solution is quite similar to the previous one, but it will work for all the devices in the same network once setup properly.

The idea for this solution is to modify the local DNS server so it knows how to resolve those private domains.

For example, if your homelab DNS is using Unbound, you could add the following as part of your Unbound config:

This solution works for every device in the LAN, however, you would still need to keep manually adding all the domains, which is something I would like to avoid.

Final solution: Unbound with Knot

This final solution is a bit more complicated, but I think it is worth the time I spent on getting to it.

Before we get to the details of the solution, we need to understand the concept of DNS zone and authoritative server in DNS. According to Akamai ^2:

Authoritative DNS is the system that keeps official records corresponding to domain names such as IP addresses.

For DNS Zone, Cloudflare had a great explanation ^3:

A DNS zone is a portion of the DNS namespace that is managed by a specific organization or administrator. A DNS zone is an administrative space which allows for more granular control of DNS components, such as authoritative nameservers.

The authoritative DNS for a DNS zone is also part of its DNS SOA record, so you can find the authoritative DNS server for google.com easily by issuing the following command:

And you will get the following response back:

We can see the authoritative DNS server for google.com zone is ns1.google.com

In the case of resolving .lan zone, the authoritative server is the router or the LAN DNS server itself. This can be verified through the following command:

Similarly, you will find the current authoritative server for raspberrypi.lan zone is also the router itself, because raspberrypi.lan currently belongs to the lan zone.

The solution I am going to present involves creating a zone file for raspberrypi.lan zone and have a DNS server act as authoritative server for that specific zone, and finally change my local Unbound instance so it knows to query for that server for the raspberrypi.lan zone.

Setting up the zone file and Knot as authoritative server

Raspberry Pi setup (Knot with DNS Zone)

Before we create the zone file, we need to install the Knot DNS server first. I have chosen to install this on the Raspberry Pi. Once the Knot server is installed successfully, you will need to disable the systemd-resolved and enable the Knot service:
systemctl disable systemd-resolvd.service && systemctl enable --now knot
You will next need to create a resolve.conf file with the following content:

And link this file to /etc/resolv.conf

This makes sure the Pi can have proper DNS setup after reboot.
The zone file for the raspberrypi.lan zone will look like this:

You will need to put this file at /var/lib/knot/raspberrypi.lan.zone.

Unbound setup

For the Unbound server, we will need to make use of stub-zone and local-zone. According to Unbound ^4:

The stub zone can be used to configure authoritative data to be used by the resolver that cannot be accessed using the public internet servers. This is useful for company-local data or private zones. Setup an authoritative server on a different host (or different port). Enter a config entry for Unbound with stub-addr: <ip address of host[@port]>. The Unbound resolver can then access the data, without referring to the public internet for it.

And also add the following local-zone and local-data:

The above will be needed to allow override the lan. zone that was setup in OpenWrt, it may not be needed if you use Unbound server as standalone.

You can find more about the unbound config here

Conclusion and Learnings

Private zones are essential for homelab, by using Unbound and Knot along with the appropriate zone file, you will be able to get the private domains up and running in you LAN easily.

Recently, I've done something with the DNS setup in my local networking. I learnt quite a lot along the way and have decided to write it down for my reference, and for other people who might find this useful.

Background

I have a quite simple home network setup. My main router is a Linksys WRT1200AC which is running OpenWrt 24.10 branch. I have installed Adblock, Unbound, Stubby, and many other software on this router and even after 10 years, it is still performing well.

My main homelab server is a Raspberry Pi 5 (8 GB) which I bought recently to replace my Rapsberry Pi 3. As I have mentioned in my previous articles on self hosting and nebula, this Raspberry Pi has been running quite a lot of containers along with the Traefik proxy for quite a while now.

Motivation

I often need to setup private domains within my homelab, mainly to experiment with new software. What I want to achieve is within my local LAN network, every device can resolve these private domains and whenever a new private domain is added, it will take effect automatically without my manual intervention.

For example, in my local network, wallabag.raspberrypi.lan would take me to the wallabag container and static.raspberry.lan would take me to the Nginx container, they are both running on my Raspberry Pi. And lab.raspberrypi.lan would also resolve to the IP of my Raspberry Pi without any intervention.

The rest of this article will focus on how I achieved the solution that solved both of this problem.

This is my first attempt in writing a review for the year. By writing this, I can hopefully provide myself with a clearer picture on what I had learnt in the past year and what I should be prepared for in the coming new year.

This blog

I haven't written as many posts as last year, though I still finished six posts in total. These articles are mostly about the issues I or someone within my team solved during our day-to-day work.

Meet ups

I started to attend meet ups regularly starting July 2024. I found it to be an excellent way to connect with the tech community and learn new stuff. Here are a list of highlights from each of the events I attended and things I learnt from it:

  • In July, I attended the GitHub NZ meetup. I learnt about Self-Hosted Action Runners, the speaker mentioned Azure container apps can be used as scalable self-hosted action runners. This is extremely useful for businesses with budget constraint. The talk was recorded and can be found here. Personally, I'm not a fan of Azure or anything Microsoft, so when I was at the talk, I immediately thought of doing something similar to thing on GCP with Google App Engine or on AWS using AWS Fargate. To me they are very similar to the Azure Container Apps in that they can scale up and down based on the load.
  • In August, I attended an AWS meetup, where the speaker talked about Pulumi and how to use it to reverse engineer an existing infrastructure to Pulumi code. While I'm not really a infrastructure guy, it's always interesting to learn something new. I do still prefer to use Terraform if I were to start a new project. I'm well aware learning Terraform language is not really as straightforward, it is still the de factor tool/language for IaC (infrastructure as code).
  • In September, I attended several meet ups. My personal favorite was the Golang meetup. The speakers talked about the newly added Go 1.23 iterators, Wails. I haven't really done any Golang professionally, however, I did several projects using Golang in my spare time, and I'm really amazed by how easy it is to use Go. Regarding the iterators, the speaker had a demo repo here. The runner up for my personal favorite was the Java meetup, the speaker talked about the virtual threads in Java and how it differed from other languages. Personally, I haven't touched Java for a while, and learning about the new Java language feature is always a good thing.
  • In October, I also attended several meet ups. I personally really liked the talk given by one of the Google Developer Expert in Web Technologies. The talk focused on the core web vitals and how to optimize them. As a backend dev, it is always good to learn something new about the frontend. The speaker had put the repo here
  • In November, I attended the Hack the Box Meetup in Auckland. This is the first ever hack the box event I attended, and I found it really interesting. Hack the Box as a platform is really useful for people to learn about hacking and pen test.
  • In December, I attended the Devfest in Nanning, China. This is the first tech event I attended in China. The topics are mostly about AI. Some interesting talks include using LLM for data analytics, and building Multidimensional Intangible Cultural Heritage Experience Platform with BERT and TensorFlow.

From next year, I will start to write weekly or monthly recap blog to summarize what I learnt from the each of the meetups or events I attended.

Tooling (I Open Source)

Full disclosure: I'm not affiliated with any of the projects mentioned here.

This year marks the marks the third year I worked in the current company. It is also the forth year that I use NeoVim as a development tool. In addition to NeoVim, I found a lot of useful tools this year for my terminal centric workflow. I might write some blog post about them next year, but as a preview, here's the list of tools I discovered and continued to use in my day-to-day workflow:

  • Hurl: Hurl is a wrapper around the og curl. It is much much easier to use than curl. For example, you can create a Hurl file (in plain text), and use it as an alternative to curl. You can also use it as a sanity or smoke testing tool. Being plain text means you can commit it a git repository and keep track of things easily.
  • Scalar: This could be a good open source alternative to Postman.
  • Redocly: Redocly is a open source tool focus around OpenAPI and swagger docs. I had used it in our project at work to combine multiple swagger docs into one big giant combined one.
  • DuckDB: To me personally, DuckDB is like SQLite but much much more powerful than that. I had used it to query JSON and CSV files directly without converting them to anything SQL. You basically get the best of both SQL and NoSQL when you integrate DuckDB.
  • Visidata: A tool to explore data. Well, it's probably similar but different from DuckDB, you can use it to explore data in various format. It's super useful if you have a terminal centric workflow like me.
  • Lyrebird: This one may be hard to sale because they do not have English documentation. However, it is a really powerful tool to capture and mock HTTP requests. It is meant to be used as a platform for automation testing, but it is much useful than that. I will create a dedicated post about this next year.

This year I consumed quite a lot of articles, my main source of technical articles comes from Hacker News and Lobster. I also have a list of RSS feeds I subscribe to. Whenever I found a good article, I usually bookmark them through my self-hosted Wallabag instance running on the free Google Cloud VPS, most of these articles will eventually become individual episodes in a podcast I can listen and consume on the go. Some of my favorite articles this year are:

  • Some Go web dev notes -- this article had inspired me to rewrite the SQL part of my personal project written in Go.
  • Three Critical Questions to Turn the Tables During Technical Interviews
  • Being Glue
  • Managers have no human rights
  • How to give a senior leader feedback (without getting fired)
  • the tech utopia fantasy is over
  • Cognitive load is what matters
  • Coding for a Finite World
  • What is a Staff Engineer?

In the new year, I plan to summarize articles I have read once a month as well, just so I have a way to reflect on what I read in the past month.

TL;DR

As a general rule (and as documented by Apple), developers should avoid setting a fixed date format, if the date is user-visible. When working with fixed format date, developer should be setting the locale and timezone to avoid any potential issues that might be caused by using client side locale or timezone.

Nowadays, it's quite common for an iOS or Android app to include a webview, and at the company I worked in, we have a similar setup -- the app would hand over to a webview and the user would continue their journey in the web. Recently, an incident related to this particular functionality was reported to us.

What happened

To explain things better, I've created this sequence diagram below that represents a working scenario:

sequenceDiagramAPP->>webview: set a token as cookie in the webview.destroy APPwebview->>APP: cookie is set.webview->>Web App: Attempted to redirect to xxxx using the cookie.Web App->>Web App: Grab the token from cookie.Web App->>Backend: Check if this token is valid.Backend->>Web App: This is a valid token, authentication successful.Web App->>webview: Go to xxxx.

In the incident, however, the user is unable to proceed to xxxx, because the web app was sending an empty token to the Backend, causing the Backend to reject it.

Investigation and Root Cause Analysis

We need to be able to reproduce the issue first before we can further our investigation into this. However, this turned out to be a tricky one as none of the devs were able to reproduce the issue on their device or simulator.

The iOS devs tend to think this is related to the web app or the Backend itself, or a rare bug in iOS webview. With the help from a web developer, we added a log so we can see how often this issue happens in production.

A week after that, we realized the issue is not just impacting 2 or 3 users but a lot more. So we decided to have another look at the App source code.

Here's the relevant part of the code:

To people who are not familiar with Swift, this may not mean anything. However, it's not difficult to guess what this part of the code is doing. It first setup a formatter, and then use that formatter to create an expiry date (from the date it gets from the Backend) as the cookie. And then the cookie was given to the webview to set to the cookieStore.

What could go wrong here? My first instinct is where the cookieExpireDate is set. The fallback is set to 1 second, that is definitely too short, but that may not be the issue.

I subsequently looked up the dateFormatter online, among the documentation provide by Apple1, there's a link to a technical FAQ2. This was the key to finding the root cause. I will quote part of the FAQ document here:

[...]
Q: I'm using NSDateFormatter to parse an Internet-style date, but this fails for some users in some regions. I've set a specific date format string; shouldn't that force NSDateFormatter to work independently of the user's region settings?
A: No. While setting a date format string will appear to work for most users, it's not the right solution to this problem. There are many places where format strings behave in unexpected ways. For example:
A user can change their calendar (using System Preferences > Language & Region > Calendar on OS X, or Settings > General > International > Calendar on iOS). In that case NSDateFormatter will treat the numbers in the string you parse as if they were in the user's chosen calendar. For example, if the user selects the Buddhist calendar, parsing the year "2010" will yield an NSDate in 1467, because the year 2010 on the Buddhist calendar was the year 1467 on the (Gregorian) calendar that we use day-to-day.
[...]
On the other hand, if you're working with fixed-format dates, you should first set the locale of the date formatter to something appropriate for your fixed format. In most cases the best locale to choose is "en_US_POSIX", a locale that's specifically designed to yield US English results regardless of both user and system preferences. "en_US_POSIX" is also invariant in time (if the US, at some point in the future, changes the way it formats dates, "en_US" will change to reflect the new behaviour, but "en_US_POSIX" will not), and between machines ("en_US_POSIX" works the same on iOS as it does on OS X, and as it it does on other platforms).

Upon reading this, I immediately set my simulator to use Buddhist calendar, and
not surprisingly, I was able to reproduce the issue. Setting a breakpoint in
the code, I saw the cookieExpireDate had a year 1481 in it. This caused the
webview to ignore this cookie, and led to all the subsequent issues.

Solutions

There are several ways of fixing this issue, however, I do want to note first, Apple no longer recommends using DateFormatter in Swift. With this in mind, the solutions can be one of the following:

Completely remove the need to format the date in APP

To me, this is the optimal solution, the app should not handle the formatting of the date -- it should take whatever it got from the App Backend (assuming App Backend is sending the correct format).

Refactor to use the Date.style

I will skip this part as I'm not proficient enough in Swift to give the correct code.

Fix the existing code by adding a fix locale (and timezone)

The updated code would be

Unfortunately fixing only this part does not mean we are done. To be on the safe side of things, we had to search through our codebase and see whether we are using similar patterns to set the format elsewhere.

Lessons Learnt

This is the first incident related to Date in my career. As a developer, whenever we are doing anything related to date or timezone, we need to be extra careful, this is especially true for the frontend.

  • Frontend (web, mobile, etc.) clients could be using different locale and timezone.As a general rule (and as documented by Apple), developers should avoid setting a fixed date format, if the date is user-visible. When working with fixed format date, developer should be setting the locale and timezone to avoid any potential issues that might be caused by using client side locale or timezone.

  • Checking the documentation of the API will always provide some good leads for debugging.

References

Last Thursday afternoon, we received an email from a colleague in our company, she mentioned the video in our app was not playing correctly. And what's strange about this is, the issue only impacted iOS users and not Android users, this usually indicates the problem is not with our app (or the back-end). The subsequent investigation on this turned out to be very interesting.

Locating the issue

We suspected this was a issue with media codec at first: iOS does not offer the variety of codecs that are supported on Android, therefore, would be much easier to get into an issue like this. However, the person reported this issue also mentioned the video was working fine a few days ago, so it's highly unlikely this is the source of the issue.

The next step was to look through the logs. We discovered there were quite a lot of errors thrown on connection reset from our identity gateway. This turned out to be a red herring -- we played the video in Android and the same error appeared.

On the right track

Desperate for more clues, we turned to one of the more experienced engineers from the other team for help. He asked me to share the headers that's sent with the video requests. This turned out to be helpful and eventually got us to the root cause.

Here are some of the request headers sent from the iOS app:

And the corresponding response headers:

Several interesting observations can be made based on the headers:

  • Range header from request headers has a value of 0-1.
  • Content-Length header from response headers, has a value of 52139111.
  • The response from the server has a status code of 200.

The obvious issue here seems to be the Content-Length header is much much larger than what's in the Range header.

With this in mind, I started to search for more information on the range header, the first step is to read the docs

Locating the cause

Reading the Docs

According to MDN:

The Range HTTP request header indicates the parts of a resource that the server should return.[...]If the server sends back ranges, it uses the 206 Partial Content status code for the response.[...]A server that doesn't support range requests may ignore the Range header and return the whole resource with a 200 status code.

Just by reading this paragraph, we know the server didn't support the Range header, therefore, it is returning 200 status code, which is what's causing the iOS video player to misbehave.

Complication and solution

Normally, at this point, one would be able to change their web server settings and add the support for Range header, and the problem would potentially be solved.

However, we have a complex infrastructure within the company, and request/response will go through several layers of (reverse) proxy before it finially reaches origin/client. This means, request/response from the server could be different from the origin. So we had to locate where exactly the issue happened in the request chain.

We first made a request without going through the reverse proxy (on the reverse proxy host itself):

And we got this back:

Then we made another request, and this time, we go through the proxy by using localhost:

And we got this back (❗❗):

Clearly the issue is with the reverse proxy itself. It turned out there was some workaround applied in the origin server and not on the reverse proxy.

According to the engineer who helped us with this:

This is necessary because the gzip FilterChain only works with byte ranges when the content-type is handled by one of the providers in the chain.

We apply the exact config to the reverse proxy, and the issue was fixed.

The Why

The problem was solved, however, I still don't get why this was the case, why Apple decides to send the range header.

According to their document:

HTTP servers hosting media files for iOS must support byte-range requests, which iOS uses to perform random access in media playback.

So it looks like the reason for requiring the support of this header is to be able to perform random access in media playback in iOS.

It also proposed ways to verify the support using Curl (which is similar to what I wrote above):

If you are not sure whether your media server supports byte-range requests, you can open the Terminal application in OS X and use the curl command-line tool to download a short segment from a file on the server:
curl --range 0-99 http://example.com/test.mov -o /dev/null
If the tool reports that it downloaded 100 bytes, the media server correctly handled the byte-range request. If it downloads the entire file, you may need to update the media server.

Lessons learnt

  • Initial assumptions can be misleading. Despite suspecting media codec issues, the problem was actually with HTTP headers and byte-range requests.
  • Consult the correct documentation will almost always speed things up. In this case, MDN is really really helpful.
  • Different platforms (iOS vs. Android) have unique requirements and behaviors. Understanding these nuances, such as iOS's requirement for byte-range support, is necessary for smooth operation.

References

https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/AppleApplications/Reference/SafariWebContent/CreatingVideoforSafarioniPhone/CreatingVideoforSafarioniPhone.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40006514-SW6
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Range

In this article, I'm going to write about what I learnt from solving an issue I encountered during a refactoring of existing code.

Background

In a TypeScript project, we used the following tsconfig file:

In our existing code, we have a js/ts file that's only exporting an array of numbers as default export like below:

In another file, we are utilizing dynamic import feature, to import the module above:

The issue

When running the above code using TypeScript, many people (including me) would expect the code above to print [1,2,3,4,5,6]. However, it would actually be printing {default: [1,2,3,4,5,6]}. This has puzzled me so much that I dig into why this is happening.

What happened

To put in short, TypeScript or my misunderstanding of TypeScript is why this was happening. With this in mind, we can examine what TypeScript emit based on the above tsconfig and code.

In the code above emitted from TypeScript compiler, we can make several observations:

  • nums.js, which was written in ECMAScript module syntax, was compiled to CommonJS module.
  • usage.ts, which utilized dynamic import (a ECMAScript feature) was basically not touched.
  • usage.js (which uses ECMAScript dynamic import) is importing nums.js (which is CommonJS)

To me, the last observation was the most suspicious, and that's where I begin my investigation.

Investigation

Why is CommonJS emitted from TypeScript, when the TypeScript code I wrote was clearly ECMAScript module?

This is actually because of the tsconfig file. According to TypeScript documentation:

The emitted JavaScript uses either CommonJS or ES2020 output depending on the file extension and the value of the type setting in the nearest package.json.

This implies, if you want TypeScript to emit ECMAScript modules, you will have to either specify by using file extension or add type: module inside the nearest package.json. In all other cases, it will emit CommonJS by default, so in the example given, since I didn't had type: module inside a package.json, CommonJS will be emitted. BUT, dynamic import is still a ECMAScript feature, this leads to the next question.

Why was the emitted JavaScript code behaving like that?

This is an interesting question. In short, it is behaving as it's supposed to and this has to do with how CommonJS namespace works.

It is explained in detail in this NodeJS documentation:

The ECMAScript Module Namespace representation of a CommonJS module is always a namespace with a default export key pointing to the CommonJS module.exports value.

And because dynamic import is a ECMAScript module feature, the end result of the dynamic import will always be a ECMAScript Module Namespace representation, and therefore, it will always wrap whatever you exported in a key called default.

Solutions

Based on the investigation, we obviously need to come up with some solutions, to make the code work as what we want it to be. There are several ways:

Change the extension

We can simply change the extension of nums.js file from .js to .mjs, by doing this, TypeScript will no longer convert things to ES2020 format, and you will no longer have this issue.

Change the dynamic import to require

This is probably less ideal, but it's also a solution. You can simply avoid using the dynamic import and use CommonJS import.

Further readings:
https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#module
https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/modules/theory.html#the-module-output-format
https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/FAQ
https://nodejs.org/docs/latest-v18.x/api/esm.html
https://nodejs.org/api/esm.html#commonjs-namespaces
https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/FAQ#common-bugs-that-arent-bugs

I build and maintain a bunch of documents in Latex, though I'm not an expert in Latex, I still found it easier to maintain than keeping a Word document around -- whenever I want to modify things, I would open Tex Studio, modify and then rebuild. The generated PDF is symlink to my desktop for easy access when I need to attach it. This works well till last Friday. I modify things, and the generated PDF did not reflect any of the changes I made. What could be the problem?

Locate the problem

Well, it wasn't really easy to diagnose the issue from the Tex Studio interface -- every time I rebuilt, it looks as if it was generating new docs but it wasn't actually doing that (cause the speed was simply too fast). So, the solution was to use CLI -- I got the actual command from settings in Tex Studio.

I first ran: xelatex -synctex=1 -interaction=nonstopmode -output-directory=build "document".tex

What I got was:

/var/lib/texmf/web2c/xetex/xelatex.fmt made by different executable version, strings are different

Well, to be honest, this error message wasn't helpful at all. It still wasn't clear what the issue was. But it's still worth looking it up.

Attempted Solutions

❌ fmtutil

This was among many of the top links I found by Googling ^1. So it was the first solution I tried -- running

It didn't fix the issue, still failing.

❌ reinstall packages

Normally this would have solved the issue, so I next attempted to reinstall the packages related to Latex. I ran:

Didn't solve the issue either.

✅ Read the Wiki carefully

Well, this should have been the first thing I tried, but I didn't. The ArchLinux Wiki here outlined the packages that's packaged by Arch and available to use.

So I installed the xetex package sudo pacman -S texlive-xetex, and then everything got back to normal.

Lessons learnt

While I still don't understand what was the exact cause of this issue, it is most likely caused by this changes made a year ago. But I don't really believe that cause I remember using the Tex Studio fine in March. But anyway, here's what I learnt:

  • Read the Wiki: ArchLinux Wiki is really really useful. Even if you are not an Arch user, chances are, you can get something out of it. So this should be the first place to look at when you are facing issue.
  • pacman could locate package: While it is not useful in this case, it's good to know pacman can locate the package that a file belongs to. Either of the command would work:
